Firstly, Scrabble tournaments require players to have a certain level of vocabulary and spelling skills, which are typically developed later in life through reading, education, and experience. A two-year-old child has not yet developed these skills to the necessary level to compete in a Scrabble tournament.

Secondly, Scrabble tournaments are typically played with adults or older children who have played the game for a while and have a good understanding of strategy and the rules. A two-year-old child may not have the patience or attention span required to play an entire game and may not be able to understand and apply the rules correctly.

Thirdly, Scrabble tournaments require players to be able to read and write, and a two-year-old child is too young to do so. Even if a two-year-old child had memorized some words, they would not be able to spell them or read them when presented on the game board.

Therefore, it is highly unlikely that a two-year-old child could win a Scrabble tournament. The answer to the question is (B) no.
